overview: A comprehensive 6-lesson project-based learning module where High School students explore electrical physics, structural engineering, and industrial design by constructing functional lamps using PVC and Black Iron piping. Students will progress from low-cost prototyping with PVC to creating finished industrial-style steel lamps, utilizing materials standard in construction and trade industries. This curriculum integrates Texas STEM standards with federal TRIO objectives.
prerequisites: Completion of Algebra I (for variable equations) and basic familiarity with laboratory safety protocols.

fieldTrips.name: Tarrant County College (South Campus) - Center of Excellence for Energy Technology
fieldTrips.description: A tour of the HVAC, Electrical, and Construction Technology labs at TCC South. Students will observe industrial pipe-fitting and commercial wiring on a large scale.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Directly correlates to the pipe-fitting and electrical wiring skills learned in the classroom, showing the collegiate pathway for these trades.

fieldTrips.name: The Perot Museum of Nature and Science - Texas Instruments Engineering and Innovation Hall
fieldTrips.description: Exploration of the Engineering Hall, specifically exhibits focusing on circuits, structures, and materials science.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Reinforces the physics concepts of electricity and structural integrity utilized in the lamp design process.

activities.title: Lesson 1: The Physics of Light & Electrical Safety
activities.description: Students learn the fundamentals of AC electricity, circuit safety, and how to use a multimeter before touching construction materials. This establishes the safety baseline for the course.
learningObjectives: Understand basic AC current flow and the function of hot, neutral, and ground wires.
Demonstrate proper safety protocols for handling electrical components.
Identify the components of a standard lamp socket assembly.
teks: Physics 112.39(c)(5)(F): Design, construct, and calculate in terms of current through, potential difference across, resistance of, and power used by electric circuit elements.
Integrated Physics and Chemistry 112.38(c)(5)(A): Demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations.

detailed: Draw a complete circuit on the whiteboard showing source, load, and ground.
Demonstrate the tactile feel of stripping wire without cutting the copper strands using 14-gauge or 16-gauge strippers.
Detail the breakdown: Black (Hot/Load), White (Neutral), Green/Bare (Ground).
Show students how to set the multimeter to the Continuity (beep) setting to test for broken wires.
Take a 6-inch piece of spare wire and practice stripping 1/2 inch of insulation off both ends.
Touch multimeter probes to opposite ends of the wire; listen for the tone to confirm continuity.
Draw a schematic in your notebook labeling the Plug, Switch, Socket, and Bulb.
Complete the safety assessment with 100% accuracy before proceeding to tools.

allowableServices: Exposure to Engineering and Tech Careers
allowableCosts: Equipment (Multimeters - if useful life > 1 year and cost < $5000)
trioCompliance.justification: Direct instruction in physics (electricity) meets the mandatory curriculum requirement for UB/UBMS.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b) - Instruction in laboratory science
edgarCitations: 2 CFR 200.453 - Materials and supplies costs, including costs of computing devices

stemConnections.science: Physics of electricity, electron flow, and conductivity.
stemConnections.math: Ohm's Law calculations (Voltage = Current x Resistance).

activities.title: Lesson 2: Design, BOM, and Budgeting
activities.description: Students use engineering design principles to sketch their lamp concepts. They must calculate the necessary pipe lengths and create a Bill of Materials (BOM) based on real-world pricing from Lowe's/Home Depot.
learningObjectives: Create orthographic sketches of a 3D object.
Calculate total project cost using a Bill of Materials.
Differentiate between fitting types (elbows, tees, flanges, couplings).
teks: Engineering Design and Presentation I 130.362(c)(5)(A): Sketch and draw using orthographic projections.

Mathematical Models with Applications 111.43(c)(1)(B): Use a problem-solving model that incorporates analyzing given information, formulating a plan or strategy, determining a solution, justifying the solution, and evaluating the problem-solving process.

materialsList.item: Lowe's/Home Depot Printed Catalogs or Tablets for Price Lookup

detailed: Explain that 1/2 inch NPT pipe actually has an outer diameter closer to 0.84 inches (critical for design).
Pass around physical examples of an Elbow 90, Street Elbow, Tee, and Floor Flange.
Demonstrate how to locate specific black iron pipe SKUs on Home Depot or Lowe's websites.
Establish the project constraints: Total materials must not exceed $30.00.
Draw a 'Front View' and 'Side View' of your lamp on graph paper.
Label every joint (e.g., '1/2 inch 90-degree elbow').
List every single part required in a spreadsheet column.
Look up prices for each part, sum the total, and modify the design if the cost exceeds $30.

trioCompliance.justification: This lesson focuses on applied mathematics (budgeting, geometry) and engineering design, satisfying the math instruction component.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402E(b) - Exposure to new technologies

stemConnections.technology: Online database research for parts sourcing.
stemConnections.engineering: Drafting and design logic; component compatibility.

collegePathways: A.A.S. Computer Aided Drafting and Design

activities.title: Lesson 3: PVC Prototype Construction
activities.description: Students build their lamp structures using Schedule 40 PVC. This allows for low-cost errors and learning threading/fitting mechanics before moving to expensive steel.
learningObjectives: Measure and cut PVC pipe to specific design lengths.
teks: Principles of Architecture 130.42(c)(10)(B): Use appropriate tools and equipment safely.
Geometry 111.41(c)(11)(B): Determine the area of composite two-dimensional figures comprised of combinations of polygons and circles (relevant to base stability).

detailed: Show how to ratchet the PVC cutters slowly to get a straight cut; do not force it.
Explain that we are 'dry fitting' (no glue) because we reuse these parts for the next class, but real plumbing requires solvent welding.
Discuss the Center of Gravity: if the lamp head extends too far forward, the base must be heavy or wide enough to counter it.
Maintain strict supervision at the cutting station to ensure fingers remain clear of blades.
Using your BOM from Lesson 2, mark the cut lines on the long PVC pipe with a marker.
Use the ratcheting cutters to create your pipe segments.
Press the pipes into the fittings firmly to assemble the lamp shape.
Place the lamp on a flat surface. Tap it gently. If it falls, you must redesign the legs/base.

allowableCosts: Workshop materials (PVC pipe is a consumable supply)
trioCompliance.justification: Hands-on engineering fabrication. While valid for UB, this aligns strongly with UBMS goals of providing intensive STEM experiences.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402E(b) - Hands-on experience in laboratories

activities.title: Lesson 4: Wiring the PVC Lamp
activities.description: Students install the electrical components into their PVC prototype. They will pull wire through the tubing and wire the socket. This bridges the structural build with the electrical theory.
learningObjectives: Successfully fish electrical wire through a tubular conduit.
Wire a polarized plug and socket correctly (Hot to Brass, Neutral to Silver).
Tie an Underwriter's Knot for strain relief.
teks: Principles of Construction 130.42(c)(10)(C): Demonstrate knowledge of electrical safety.
Physics 112.39(c)(5)(E): Characterize materials as conductors or insulators.

detailed: Demonstrate the 'Underwriter's Knot' which prevents the wire from being ripped out of the socket terminals if the cord is yanked.
Show close-ups of the wire insulation: Ribbed/Squared is Neutral, Smooth/Round is Hot.
Explain that the wide blade on a plug is Neutral, connecting to the silver screw, ensuring the threaded socket shell is never electrified.
Physically inspect every student's connections before allowing them to close the socket shell.
Feed the cut end of the lamp cord from the bottom of the PVC base up to the top opening.
Separate the two wires about 2 inches down and strip 1/2 inch off the ends.
Tie the Underwriter's Knot inside the socket base.
Connect the Smooth (Hot) wire to the Brass screw and the Ribbed (Neutral) wire to the Silver screw. Tighten clockwise.
Snap the socket shell together until it clicks.

trioCompliance.justification: Direct application of physics principles. The lamp kits are allowable supplies as they are necessary for the instruction of electrical circuits.

activities.title: Lesson 5: Industrial Steel Lamp Build
activities.description: Students graduate to Black Iron Pipe. This involves handling heavier materials, cleaning industrial grease, and dealing with thread friction. This lesson simulates real-world trade work.
learningObjectives: Assemble threaded steel pipe with proper torque.
Compare material properties of PVC vs. Steel (density, rigidity).
teks: Manufacturing Engineering Technology II 130.369(c)(6)(B): Perform material processing.
Chemistry 112.35(c)(4)(A): Differentiate between physical and chemical changes and properties (oxidation/rust prevention).

materialsList.item: 1/2 inch Black Iron Pipe Nipples (various lengths)

detailed: Warn students that black iron pipes come coated in protective oil that stains clothes. Gloves are mandatory.
Discuss 'Galvanic Corrosion' (Science connection) - why we don't mix copper and steel directly without a dielectric union usually.
Explain that pipe threads are tapered (NPT), meaning they get tighter as you turn them, creating a mechanical seal.
Demonstrate how to thoroughly degrease the pipe before assembly so the lamp is clean for home use.
Put on gloves. Spray degreaser on the iron pipes and wipe aggressively with rags until the black oil is gone.
Screw the vertical pipe into the heavy floor flange.
Feed the electrical wire through the pipes *as you build*. You cannot push the wire through sharp iron elbows after the lamp is fully built.
Tighten all connections by hand, then use a tool (or strong grip) to add a 1/4 turn for security.

allowableServices: Exposure to Career and Technical Education (CTE)
trioCompliance.justification: Provides exposure to skilled trades and engineering materials. Allowable as an enrichment workshop material cost.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b) - Exposure to career opportunities

activities.title: Lesson 6: Final Wiring, Testing, and Analysis
activities.description: Final wiring of the steel lamp, bulb installation, safety testing, and a cost/benefit analysis presentation comparing the PVC prototype to the Steel final product.
learningObjectives: Complete the manufacturing assembly of a consumer product.
Present a cost-benefit analysis of materials used.
teks: Scientific Research and Design 130.372(c)(2)(H): Communicate valid conclusions supported by the data through various methods such as lab reports, labeled drawings, or graphic organizers.
Economics with Emphasis on the Free Enterprise System 118.4(c)(2)(B): Analyze the relationship between cost and production.

detailed: Perform a continuity check on every lamp to ensure no short circuits exist before plugging into the wall.
Facilitate a discussion: The PVC lamp cost $12, the Steel lamp cost $30. Why would a customer pay $60 for the steel one? (Aesthetics, Durability).
Briefly discuss Thomas Edison, the carbon filament, and the shift to LED efficiency.
Use the rubric to evaluate student communication skills during their analysis presentation.
Wire the final socket on the steel lamp using the skills from Lesson 4.
Stick felt pads to the bottom of the iron flange to prevent it from scratching furniture.
Install the LED bulb, plug it in, and switch it on (after teacher approval).
Stand and present: Total Cost, Hardest Challenge, and One Improvement you would make for Version 2.0.

trioCompliance.justification: The final presentation solidifies the academic learning objectives (Math/Science analysis). The supplies remain allowable as project materials.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b) - Instruction in core curriculum
